benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Modify custom fields to account

covered: PUT - Valid Request: Multiple success paths verify 204 and data persistence (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC15, TC16, TC17).
PUT - Non-Existing Resource: Proper error handling for non-existent accountId with 400 (TC07).

Input validation around the request (story-aligned): required header present/missing (TC01, TC08), UUID format validation (TC06), missing/malformed body (TC09, TC10), invalid body schema (TC11), optional headers supported (TC02), unsupported headers ignored (TC05).
gaps: PUT - Partial Update: No explicit tests define whether PUT replaces the full set of custom fields or allows partial/merge semantics; absence of tests that ensure partial updates are rejected unless allowed.
PUT - Concurrency Issues: No scenarios for race conditions when multiple clients update the same account concurrently (e.g., last-write-wins vs. optimistic locking using ETag/If-Match or version).
Success response contract: No checks that a 204 response has an empty body and correct Content-Type/headers as per spec (produces application/json is mentioned but ambiguous for 204).
Non-Existing Resource status semantics: Only 400 is tested; no clarity on 404 vs 400 differentiation if the system uses 404 for unknown accountId.
recommendations: Add scenarios to clarify and verify PUT semantics: send a subset of fields and assert whether the server fully replaces existing custom fields or rejects partial updates. Include a test where omitted existing fields are removed after PUT if full-replace is intended.

Add same-resource concurrency tests: two concurrent PUTs to the same account. Validate conflict handling (e.g., 412 with If-Match) or defined last-write-wins. Include an interleaving update to expose race conditions.
Validate success response contract: assert 204 has no body and confirm any required headers. If the API advertises application/json, verify it only appears where appropriate (non-204 responses).
Clarify and add a scenario for non-existent account status code semantics (400 vs 404) to align with API standards and documentation.
